symptoms: Powdery mildew on cherry manifests as a white or grayish powdery growth on leaves, stems, and fruit, potentially causing leaf distortion and reduced fruit quality.
remedies: Prune infected branches to improve air circulation. Apply neem oil every 7-14 days as a natural fungicide. Use sulfur-based fungicides according to label instructions. Ensure good air circulation around trees by proper spacing. Remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected fruit. Apply a baking soda spray (1 tsp per liter of water) weekly. Select cherry varieties with powdery mildew resistance. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization. Monitor trees regularly for early signs of infection. Use copper-based fungicides as a preventative measure before symptoms appear.
